title: How to Configure Flutter Flavors for iOS with Xcode
subtitle: Learn how to configure multiple Flutter environments on iOS using Xcode schemes and build configurations—development, staging, and production
metaTitle: Flutter iOS Flavors Setup: Step-by-Step Guide with Xcode Schemes
metaDescription: Master Flutter iOS flavors with this step-by-step tutorial. Configure Xcode schemes, duplicate build configurations, update your Podfile, and set environment variables for development, staging, and production builds.

text.content: Is the setup of Flutter flavors for iOS a nightmare? Do you get lost in the Xcode schemes on your Flutter projects? Did you configure your environments for Android, pushed the changes to the, only to be told by the Mac users that it won’t run for Apple builds?

rich_text.plain_text: Is the setup of Flutter flavors for iOS a nightmare? Do you get lost in the Xcode schemes on your Flutter projects? Did you configure your environments for Android, pushed the changes to the, only to be told by the Mac users that it won’t run for Apple builds?

text.content: This is something similar to what we experienced in

text.content: What Are Flutter Flavors? (and why you need them)

rich_text.plain_text: What Are Flutter Flavors? (and why you need them)

text.content: But first, let's go to the most basics. What

rich_text.plain_text: But first, let's go to the most basics. What
are
flavors?

text.content: Flutter flavors are separate environments of your app, each with its own configuration.

rich_text.plain_text: Flutter flavors are separate environments of your app, each with its own configuration.

text.content: They let you build different versions of the same app. Same codebase, different behavior.

rich_text.plain_text: They let you build different versions of the same app. Same codebase, different behavior.

text.content: You typically use them to separate:

rich_text.plain_text: You typically use them to separate:
development

text.content: → unstable features, debug tools, local backend

rich_text.plain_text: → unstable features, debug tools, local backend
staging
→ your testing/pre-production environment
production

text.content: → the real deal for App Store users

rich_text.plain_text: → the real deal for App Store users
Why do you need them?

text.content: So you don’t accidentally test on production (although it happens more often than you'd think)

rich_text.plain_text: So you don’t accidentally test on production (although it happens more often than you'd think)

text.content: So your teammates run the same environment through consistent configs.

rich_text.plain_text: So your teammates run the same environment through consistent configs.

text.content: So CI/CD can build the correct version of your app.

rich_text.plain_text: So CI/CD can build the correct version of your app.
In short:

text.content: Flavors give structure to your development workflow, help prevent disasters, and make releasing dramatically safer.

rich_text.plain_text: Flavors give structure to your development workflow, help prevent disasters, and make releasing dramatically safer.

text.content: And while Flutter handles flavors smoothly on Android,

rich_text.plain_text: And while Flutter handles flavors smoothly on Android,

text.content: iOS requires an extra layer of setup because everything relies on Xcode (like usual): schemes, build configurations, and manual linking.

rich_text.plain_text: iOS requires an extra layer of setup because everything relies on Xcode (like usual): schemes, build configurations, and manual linking.

text.content: That’s what we fix in this tutorial.

rich_text.plain_text: That’s what we fix in this tutorial.

text.content: How Flavors Work on iOS (Schemes + Configurations)

rich_text.plain_text: How Flavors Work on iOS (Schemes + Configurations)

text.content: Here’s the mental model that makes everything click:

rich_text.plain_text: Here’s the mental model that makes everything click:
On iOS, a
flavor
is not a single thing.
It’s a combination of:

text.content: 1. A Scheme → what you choose to run

rich_text.plain_text: 1. A Scheme → what you choose to run

text.content: 2. A Build Configuration → how Xcode actually compiles it

rich_text.plain_text: 2. A Build Configuration → how Xcode actually compiles it

text.content: Schemes = “which version of the app do you want to run?”

rich_text.plain_text: Schemes = “which version of the app do you want to run?”

text.content: Think of schemes as the “entry points” to your environments. When you run a scheme, Xcode needs to know how to build it, and that’s where build configurations come in.

rich_text.plain_text: Think of schemes as the “entry points” to your environments. When you run a scheme, Xcode needs to know how to build it, and that’s where build configurations come in.

text.content: Build Configurations = “how should this version behave?”

rich_text.plain_text: Build Configurations = “how should this version behave?”

text.content: By default, Xcode gives you three:

rich_text.plain_text: By default, Xcode gives you three:
Debug
Release
Profile

text.content: For flavors, you duplicate these into:

rich_text.plain_text: For flavors, you duplicate these into:
Debug-development
Debug-staging
Debug-production
etc.

text.content: Each configuration contains the actual rules for building your app:

rich_text.plain_text: Each configuration contains the actual rules for building your app:
compiler settings
optimizations
environment variables
build flags
signing settings
Podfile behavior
Putting it together:
A scheme (ex:
development

text.content: ) must be linked to a matching set of build configurations:

rich_text.plain_text: ) must be linked to a matching set of build configurations:

text.content: If a scheme points to the wrong configuration, the build will run… but with the wrong environment. (Which is exactly the nightmare you experienced.)

rich_text.plain_text: If a scheme points to the wrong configuration, the build will run… but with the wrong environment. (Which is exactly the nightmare you experienced.)
In one sentence:

text.content: Schemes tell Xcode what to run; build configurations tell Xcode how to build it.

rich_text.plain_text: Schemes tell Xcode what to run; build configurations tell Xcode how to build it.

text.content: Once both are connected correctly (and the Podfile is updated), your iOS flavors behave exactly like Android flavors—clean, predictable, and CI-friendly.

rich_text.plain_text: Once both are connected correctly (and the Podfile is updated), your iOS flavors behave exactly like Android flavors—clean, predictable, and CI-friendly.

Create schemes (

) for each of your flavors.

Update the Podfile (the

text.content: Step-by-Step: Configure Flutter Flavors on iOS with Xcode Schemes

rich_text.plain_text: Step-by-Step: Configure Flutter Flavors on iOS with Xcode Schemes

text.content: If you are need more details, this is your place.

rich_text.plain_text: If you are need more details, this is your place.

text.content: In the step-by-step guide below, we’ll create your schemes, duplicate and name your build configurations, connect everything cleanly, update the Podfile so CocoaPods behaves, and wire up your environment variables the right way. By the end, your iOS flavors will work exactly as intended — no mismatched builds, no mystery errors, no flavor accidentally running production (we’ve all been there).

rich_text.plain_text: In the step-by-step guide below, we’ll create your schemes, duplicate and name your build configurations, connect everything cleanly, update the Podfile so CocoaPods behaves, and wire up your environment variables the right way. By the end, your iOS flavors will work exactly as intended — no mismatched builds, no mystery errors, no flavor accidentally running production (we’ve all been there).
1. Open the Project in Xcode
The Xcode project is on
/ios/Runner.xcodeproj

Runner

text.content: : Double check that your schemes are shared. For that, open the Manage Schemes window from the bar at the top and check that all the Shared checkboxes are filled. The schemes need to be shared so that they can be accessed by Flutter.

3. Duplicate Build Configurations
Create the configurations (
Runner
(on the project navigator)
> Info
(on the tabs at the top)
> Runner
(on the PROJECT section, above TARGETS)
> + > Duplicate configuration

text.content: You'll have to duplicate each of the configurations (Debug, Release and Profile) for each one of the flavors that you are creating. Give them names for your environments (Debug-production, Debug-staging, Debug-development, etc). Use lowercase.

rich_text.plain_text: You'll have to duplicate each of the configurations (Debug, Release and Profile) for each one of the flavors that you are creating. Give them names for your environments (Debug-production, Debug-staging, Debug-development, etc). Use lowercase.

flavor

text.content: to each of the flavors you're configuring (production, staging, development).

rich_text.plain_text: to each of the flavors you're configuring (production, staging, development).
Run, Test, Analyze: Debug-[flavor]
Profile: Profile-[flavor]
Archive: Release-[flavor]

text.content: At the end, with three schemes, you must get something like this (development, staging and prouctions, from left to right):

5. Update the Podfile

text.content: As always, the pods need to be updated.

rich_text.plain_text: As always, the pods need to be updated.
Open
Podfile
in
ios/Podfile

text.content: (or macos for a mac project) from the root of your Flutter project.

rich_text.plain_text: (or macos for a mac project) from the root of your Flutter project.
expand the
project 'Runner'

text.content: code at the start of the file.

rich_text.plain_text: code at the start of the file.

text.content:
//From this
project 'Runner', {
  'Debug' => :debug,
  'Profile' => :release,
  'Release' => :release,
}

//To this (adapted to the flavors you create, of course)
project 'Runner', {
  'Debug' => :debug,
  'Debug-development' => :debug,
  'Debug-staging' => :debug,
  'Debug-production' => :debug,
  'Profile' => :release,
  'Profile-development' => :release,
  'Profile-staging' => :release,
  'Profile-production' => :release,
  'Release' => :release,
  'Release-development' => :release,
  'Release-staging' => :release,
  'Release-production' => :release,
}

rich_text.plain_text:
//From this
project 'Runner', {
  'Debug' => :debug,
  'Profile' => :release,
  'Release' => :release,
}

//To this (adapted to the flavors you create, of course)
project 'Runner', {
  'Debug' => :debug,
  'Debug-development' => :debug,
  'Debug-staging' => :debug,
  'Debug-production' => :debug,
  'Profile' => :release,
  'Profile-development' => :release,
  'Profile-staging' => :release,
  'Profile-production' => :release,
  'Release' => :release,
  'Release-development' => :release,
  'Release-staging' => :release,
  'Release-production' => :release,
}

text.content: Common Errors When Configuring Flutter iOS Flavors

rich_text.plain_text: Common Errors When Configuring Flutter iOS Flavors

text.content: Wrong scheme linked to a build configuration

rich_text.plain_text: Wrong scheme linked to a build configuration

text.content: Symptom: Your app runs but uses the wrong environment.

rich_text.plain_text: Symptom: Your app runs but uses the wrong environment.

text.content: Fix: Double-check each scheme in Xcode and ensure Run, Profile, and Archive tabs point to the correct flavor-specific configuration.

rich_text.plain_text: Fix: Double-check each scheme in Xcode and ensure Run, Profile, and Archive tabs point to the correct flavor-specific configuration.

text.content: Pods not updating for new configurations

rich_text.plain_text: Pods not updating for new configurations

text.content: Symptom: Build fails or CocoaPods errors appear.

rich_text.plain_text: Symptom: Build fails or CocoaPods errors appear.

text.content: Fix: Update the Podfile with all flavor-specific build configurations and run pod install again.

rich_text.plain_text: Fix: Update the Podfile with all flavor-specific build configurations and run pod install again.
Environment variables not passed correctly

text.content: Symptom: App crashes or uses default settings instead of the flavor config.

rich_text.plain_text: Symptom: App crashes or uses default settings instead of the flavor config.

text.content: Fix: Add your environment file paths in Xcode under “Arguments Passed on Launch” for Run and Profile tabs.

rich_text.plain_text: Fix: Add your environment file paths in Xcode under “Arguments Passed on Launch” for Run and Profile tabs.
Schemes not shared

text.content: Symptom: Flutter CLI cannot see your new flavors.

rich_text.plain_text: Symptom: Flutter CLI cannot see your new flavors.

text.content: Fix: Open Manage Schemes in Xcode and ensure the “Shared” checkbox is enabled for all schemes.

rich_text.plain_text: Fix: Open Manage Schemes in Xcode and ensure the “Shared” checkbox is enabled for all schemes.
Duplicate build configuration naming mistakes

text.content: Symptom: Xcode can’t find the configuration or uses wrong one.

rich_text.plain_text: Symptom: Xcode can’t find the configuration or uses wrong one.

text.content: Fix: Use consistent, lowercase naming (e.g., Debug-development, Release-staging) and match the scheme names exactly.

rich_text.plain_text: Fix: Use consistent, lowercase naming (e.g., Debug-development, Release-staging) and match the scheme names exactly.

text.content: FAQ: Flutter iOS Flavors & Xcode Schemes

rich_text.plain_text: FAQ: Flutter iOS Flavors & Xcode Schemes

text.content: Q1: What are Flutter flavors on iOS?

rich_text.plain_text: Q1: What are Flutter flavors on iOS?

text.content: Flutter flavors are separate environments of your app (development, staging, production) that let you run the same codebase with different configurations. On iOS, flavors require Xcode schemes and build configurations to work properly.

rich_text.plain_text: Flutter flavors are separate environments of your app (development, staging, production) that let you run the same codebase with different configurations. On iOS, flavors require Xcode schemes and build configurations to work properly.

text.content: Q2: Why do I need Xcode schemes for Flutter iOS flavors?

rich_text.plain_text: Q2: Why do I need Xcode schemes for Flutter iOS flavors?

text.content: Schemes tell Xcode which version of your app to run. Without properly linked schemes, your builds may run the wrong environment, causing mismatched behavior or crashes.

rich_text.plain_text: Schemes tell Xcode which version of your app to run. Without properly linked schemes, your builds may run the wrong environment, causing mismatched behavior or crashes.

text.content: Q3: How do I add a new flavor to my Flutter iOS project?

rich_text.plain_text: Q3: How do I add a new flavor to my Flutter iOS project?

text.content: Create a new scheme in Xcode, duplicate existing build configurations (Debug, Release, Profile) for that flavor, connect the scheme to the configurations, update your Podfile, and add environment arguments if needed.

rich_text.plain_text: Create a new scheme in Xcode, duplicate existing build configurations (Debug, Release, Profile) for that flavor, connect the scheme to the configurations, update your Podfile, and add environment arguments if needed.

text.content: Q4: Can I share Flutter flavors between Android and iOS?

rich_text.plain_text: Q4: Can I share Flutter flavors between Android and iOS?

text.content: Yes, the concept is the same, but iOS requires extra Xcode setup. Ensure your schemes, build configurations, and environment variables match across platforms for consistency.

rich_text.plain_text: Yes, the concept is the same, but iOS requires extra Xcode setup. Ensure your schemes, build configurations, and environment variables match across platforms for consistency.

text.content: Q5: Do Flutter flavors affect CI/CD pipelines?

rich_text.plain_text: Q5: Do Flutter flavors affect CI/CD pipelines?

text.content: Absolutely. Properly configured flavors let your CI/CD pipelines build the correct environment automatically, reducing errors and manual intervention.

rich_text.plain_text: Absolutely. Properly configured flavors let your CI/CD pipelines build the correct environment automatically, reducing errors and manual intervention.
A note on AI usage

text.content: Some parts of this article were generated with the help of AI. I fully encourage using AI as a tool, and I use it myself. That said, the tutorial itself was created, tested, and verified by me while actually setting up Flutter iOS flavors. Every step has been tried and proven to work, so you can follow it confidently.

rich_text.plain_text: Some parts of this article were generated with the help of AI. I fully encourage using AI as a tool, and I use it myself. That said, the tutorial itself was created, tested, and verified by me while actually setting up Flutter iOS flavors. Every step has been tried and proven to work, so you can follow it confidently.
